Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Leveraging Matched Administrative Datasets to Improve Educational Practice and Long Run Life Outcomes: Toward Building a National Interdisciplinary Network

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal intends to develop a national community of researchers that utilizes large scale, longitudinal educational databases that are linked across the spectrum of early childhood to college, workplace and other social sets of data. The research collaborative includes an initial group of scholars in education research, education policy, anthropology, economics, psychology and social sciences from Northwestern and Duke University. These researchers are actively recruiting researchers and educational stakeholders from across the country, who are working with different educational and other data sets to improve capacity to link data together in the expanded data repositories that have been funded by the federal government.

The researchers are identifying best practices in the use of data and develop prototypes of their use. Starting from the Florida and North Carolina longitudinal data sets, the researchers are developing prototypes of how these data can be combined to answer pressing educational and social science questions that have heretofore been unable to be addressed. These prototypes are being developed collaboratively across the multiple institutions who are participating in the national community, with Northwestern and Duke serving as the conceptual hubs of the project. The prototypes inform the two national level meetings at which scholars and practitioners to share findings and stimulate the development of such research in other states.

The expansion of large scale longitudinal data in education and social sciences has resulted in a demand for new ways to link together data that has typically remained in silos across various state agencies. By developing prototypes of how these data sets should be linked, this research and development is expanding the nature of the questions that the data can inform. These questions include important policy and practice concerns that have been problematic in science, technology, engineering and mathematics education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Network began in 2012 when economist Figlio and psychologist Dodge recruited about 50 academic researchers and 25 state-level education policy leaders to become founding members of the Network and to attend at least one of three NSF-sponsored Network meetings -- to date, held at Northwestern University in October 2013, at Duke University in October 2015, and in Washington, D.C., in April 2016. Together with the Council of State Governments (and with Kauffman Foundation support), we also convened a fourth meeting of 40 state-level legislative and executive branch education leaders and 10 researchers, in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, in October 2014. Recently, the Network broadened its membership to include federal education officials.

We started with previously established policy-researcher agreements forged by Figlio in Florida and Dodge in North Carolina, which provide models for how additional states might establish agreements with researchers to meet mutual goals. Through the four Network meetings, members have begun new collaborations and projects with educational policymakers in at least ten states -- Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Massachusetts, Michigan, North Carolina, Oregon, Tennessee, and Texas. We are currently exploring agreements with three more states and hope to add more over the next two years. These relationships have led to data-sharing agreements, sharing of thousands of data files, added value for these states, and dozens of scholarly articles that have advanced scientific knowledge. These experiences create templates for similar scholar-policy leader relationships in additional states and districts. On the one hand, these experiences lead to the conclusion that each situation is unique, and creating partnerships in new states will require individualized solutions to new challenges. On the other hand, these successes point toward transferable best practices in relationship-building for data sharing.

Transferable best practices provide solutions to challenges in technical exchange and management of data, data security, legal right to privacy, ethical dilemmas in ownership of data, scientific issues in matching of data files when identifiers are imprecise, human subjects issues in research, political issues in the independence of findings, and popular perceptions about education data. The Network has received guidance from the nonprofit Data Quality Campaign (DQC), championed by its President and CEO, Aimee Guidera. Guidera has served as a member of the Advisory Board for the Network, actively participated in three Network meetings to date, and at one meeting presented findings from a survey and recommendations for future data agreements. 

By addressing these issues, the Network has contributed to the development of the emerging science of education informatics, in which education policy decisions are guided by rigorous analysis of population-level longitudinal data sets that follow children across the life course. These data sets start with public education-system information, but central to this effort are carefully-guarded linkages between education data systems and other state and federal administrative data files including birth records, preschool program experiences, out-of-school community activities, arrest records, child abuse registry records, Medicaid records, employment data, military records, marriage records, offspring birth records, and federal census records.

The Network has encouraged interdisciplinary research in education policy by attracting members from economics, sociology, psychology, education, social work, anthropology, public health, and psychiatry. It has nurtured emerging scholars through support for graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and early-career scholars to attend meetings.

The Network has established a sustainable community of over 70 researchers, state education program officials, state data administrators, and federal education officials, who together use education informatics to inform and improve education policy.
